header.seo: The Healing Brigade | Aftermath: Puerto Ricans Rebuild After Maria
header.subtitle: deck here

text.value: Every night, Ingrid Morales settles down to sleep on a thin canvas cot, surrounded by water bottles, medications and other supplies soon to be on their way to the survivors of Hurricane Maria. Her 7-year-old daughter sleeps on a cot next to her, and her husband sleeps in an adjacent room also stacked with boxes of supplies.

The family isn’t sleeping at the makeshift clinic because they were displaced, like so many Puerto Ricans were after hurricanes Irma and Maria battered the island. Their home is nearby, and was relatively unscathed in the storm.

But Morales is responsible for handling the donations that Clinica Bantiox, a health clinic set up just six days after Hurricane Maria, receives from organizations around the world. She stays there to ensure that everything --  from the blood sugar meters to diapers --  stays safe overnight.

At one point, more than 100 doctors, nurses and other volunteers slept alongside the family at the clinic set up in a preschool. Now, it’s just the Morales family. A member of the administrative staff, Morales feels the responsibility is too important to abandon, but she also has  a personal reason to stay.
“I think that giving is healing,” she said.

The clinic is just one piece of the work of Iniciativa Comunitaria, a nonprofit that is helping  address health care needs after the storm. It also runs brigades that bring mobile clinics to communities around the island. The Puerto Rico-based organization has been around for over 25 years, sending brigades to respond to crises in Haiti, Guatemala and across the world.

Now, their own country is in crisis. The water levels in Toa Baja, the low-lying suburb where the clinic is located, reached nearly 20 feet during the storm, leaving some residents stranded on their roofs. In the aftermath, Iniciativa has helped more than 6,000 people between its clinic and its brigades.
The brigade’s members started their journey more than 200 days ago. It’s their longest mission ever.

Hurricane Maria is becoming a fading memory on the U.S. mainland, but Puerto Ricans  are still recovering physically and emotionally from the most devastating storm in decades. Doctors and medical professionals are needed more than ever.

Even before the storm, the financial crisis had driven doctors away from the island in search of jobs elsewhere. Between 2006 and 2016, 5,000 doctors left the island. An estimated 10 doctors have left the island per day since the storm, according to a local news outlet, furthering the medical care crisis here.

“Everything was so disrupted that their income stopped, their offices were destroyed,” said Dr. Wendy Matos, executive director of the University of Puerto Rico's faculty practice plan. “It’s like, the rug was taken out from under their feet. People made decisions to survive.”
Those who are left are picking up the pieces.
“You have to go out to serve,” said José Luis Vargas Tapia, the leader of the organization’s “Iniciativas de Paz” brigades. “You have to do it, because if not you, then who is going to do it?”
As the sun rose in Toa Baja on a Wednesday morning in March, the clinic brimmed with volunteers preparing to set off on the brigade.
They packed duffle bags full of medications and supplies: blood sugar monitors, vaccines, antibiotics. Franchely Soto darted around volunteers with a clipboard, checking off her list with precision.

Things weren’t always so organized. To set up a clinic in six days, they had to make do. The clinic inhabits one of the rooms in the preschool, and several classrooms hold supplies, including the one where Morales sleeps.

Stethoscopes hang on plastic hooks, post its and notepaper plaster the walls, and the staff sit at card tables. A curtain divides the waiting area and administrative offices from where patients are seen.
In front of the door, a sign greets patients: “We are a big hug.”
The group has been on nearly 70 brigades, and they have the process down like clockwork.

José Antonio Vargas Vidot, who is now a senator in the Puerto Rican legislature, started Iniciativa in 1990 to address HIV among drug users and the homeless. The program has grown to offer 12 different services.
Around a year after he was elected in November 2016, , his son, Vargas Tapia, took over leading the “Iniciativas de Paz” brigades.
Vargas Tapia gathers the volunteers around for their morning briefing: around 20 doctors, medical students, nurses, administrators, and anyone else who happens to be on hand that day.

The community they’re about to serve -- Aguada, a small town on the island’s west coast -- is more than 80 miles away, but Vargas Tapia talks about the patients like they’re family. Some still don’t have power or water. Fallen trees still line many roads.
“Here we have no titles, here we are human beings serving other humans,” Vargas Tapia told the group. “That's it.”

The volunteers load into a caravan of cars, and set off through the countryside, watching as the buildings of San Juan give way to lush rolling hills, where Aguada sits overlooking a valley and a glimmer of the coastline.
After unpacking their supplies in the hot sun, Vargas Tapia and his team split up to visit patients, some of whom are bedridden. They have 37 people to see that day.
On the last stop of the day for one group of volunteers, a doctor and nurse pull up to Isidra Perez’s house.

The elderly are more vulnerable to the heat, especially Perez, who is bedridden. So for the five months after the storm, her family used their generator between five and seven hours a day to run the air conditioning.
The cost of gasoline needed to run the generator added up to about $1,000. The family was nearly economically ruined.
Perez developed an ulcer not long after the storm hit, but because the roads were blocked with debris, there was no way to get to the hospital.

“At the beginning you feel desperate: no water, no light, no this, no that,” Bonilla said. “But little by little you say, ‘hello, this is something I can overcome,’ and little by little we settled.”
Because Bonilla works at a local hospital, she was able to take care of her mother, but others still struggle to access medical care.

Even though hospitals are open now, they face supply and staff shortages, and in the storm’s wake, some did not accept patients from other areas. Some patients have had to wait nearly a full day to receive treatment.
But it’s patients with long-term diseases like diabetes that are most at risk.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 15.7 percent of Puerto Ricans reported having diabetes in 2014, compared to 10.1 percent for the U.S. population as a whole. A study from the University of Puerto Rico’s Medical School found that nearly 40 percent of participants suffered from hypertension.
And a loss of power for some diabetics can be a life or death situation, as insulin needs to be refrigerated.
“The deaths after a disaster come from untreated chronic illnesses,” said Vargas Vidot. “So diabetes is endemic here. Hypertension is endemic. Cardiovascular problems are endemic.”

Those deaths aren’t reflected in the storm’s death toll, even if many wouldn’t have happened otherwise. And Matos of the University of Puerto Rico says there are other long-term health consequences that often get overlooked, like mental health and suicide risk. The number of deaths by suicide increased by 29 percent between 2016 and 2017, after years of decline. Needs a beat here about PTSD on the island, to set up next graf.

While it’s too early for most research to track the long-term mental health impacts of Hurricane Maria, a study of low-income parents in the 18 months after Hurricane Katrina found that nearly half exhibited signs of probable PTSD.

“The government disregarded the effect of a disaster on the emotional state of people,” Matos said. “That affects directly not only the thinking process and decision making, but their physical conditions too.”

value.text: “We saw Puerto Rico literally broken, If you see something broken, it’s human that you want to bring it back together.”
value.attribution: Sofia Muns, a first-year medical student at the University of Puerto Rico.

text.value: As the Inciativa’s daytime volunteers pack up and head back to Toa Baja, the night brigades are just getting started.

The group of undergraduate and medical students at the University of Puerto Rico is part of Reciento Pa La Calle, an Iniciativa program that provides services for homeless people and drug users at night.

After loading cars with supplies, the volunteers pulled their cars up to an empty bus station, where just one other car was parked. Adriana Rodriguez, a third-year medical student at the University of Puerto Rico, hopped out of her car and approached a homeless camp, scattered with tents and mattresses.
She exchanged a few words with the camp’s residents, and they light up. Rodriguez waved to her peers, who hop out of a caravan of cars labeled “Iniciativa.”

The students hand out orange juice, coffee, sandwiches, clothes, toothpaste, condoms — anything they had in their supply of donations, they provide. Several of the students dressed wounds, while other just took time to listen to the stories of people in the camps. Like René, who asked that his last name not be used, who has been the leader of the homeless camp for years. The other residents call him “El Padre.”
The storm destroyed what few things he and the others had in the camp, and the bus terminal they rely on for light was without power for a month.
René’s two daughters left for New York after the storm. TK needs another beat…. Was he homeless before that? Is this why he’s homeless? How are they doing?
The members of the camp survived though, thanks to Iniciativa’s volunteers, who brought them and others to a shelter.

But many of Puerto Rico’s homeless stayed on the streets. While the government has yet to study the island’s homeless population — Vargas Vidot is pushing for it in the Senate — estimates from several years ago were as high as 1,650.

It’s the homeless, the elderly, drug users and other “forgotten” populations that Iniciativa focuses much of its efforts on. And many of those residents and volunteers alike say government assistance is not reaching those who need it most.
“Most patients we have been seeing, they haven’t been seen by any physician or any group,” said Soto, Iniciativa’s logistics coordinator.
Many of those communities are used to helping themselves. Cantera, an impoverished community in San Juan the brigade had recently visited, formed its own nonprofit years ago, as have several others.
“There’s a concept of community that doesn’t represent a geographic thing,” said Vargas Vidot.

And on their brigades, the volunteers take that concept into to their patients’ homes. Like Hector Ortíz, who strummed his guitar inside the peach colored walls of Maria Elena’s public housing unit in Cantera.
Ortiz sang “Levanto mis manos,” or “I lift my hands,” with a group of Iniciativa’s volunteers as Maria Elena tapped her knuckles on her kitchen table to the beat and smiled.

Maria Elena lives alone, like much of the elderly population on the island. Between 2014 and 2016, the share of the population older than 65 increased from 14.5 percent to nearly 19 percent while the share of people under 18 declined, according to U.S. Census Bureau Estimates.
Since the storm, experts say it’s only gotten worse. As of January, more than 200,000 Puerto Ricans had left the island for the mainland. Most of them are the island’s youth.

“The young people are the future and if they are leaving, what’s gonna happen?” said Carla Santiago, a third-year medical student at the University of Medicine and Health Sciences on Saint Kitts and a volunteer with the brigade. “Puerto Rico needs more young people to rebuild.”
Sometimes, the elderly just need someone to talk to. Or, in Maria Elena’s case, to share a song with.

That’s what drives Iniciativa’s volunteers to rebuild  their community — whether its a town on the opposite coast of the island, a poor neighborhood in San Juan or the area just outside of the University of Puerto Rico’s medical school where the homeless sleep.

“We saw Puerto Rico literally broken,” said Sofia Muns, a first-year medical student at the University of Puerto Rico. “If you see something broken, it’s human that you want to bring it back together.”
